The islands from south to north are:

value: — the smallest proper island in the archipelago, that spent most of the 20th century getting blasted to hell by U.S. Navy training exercises
— the most active of the Mariana volcanoes, Anatahan's lava has scared off humans and even most plants alike
— while inhabited from 1900 until 1945, Sarigan is now a nature preserve, but is currently off-limits following a submarine volcanic eruption just to the south
— never supporting a permanent population, this island is home to the rare Micronesian Megapode
— sporadically inhabited, but currently vacant following evacuation in 2009 from Typhoon Choi-wan; ruins may be present of the village on the northwest coast
— two volcanoes connected by a strip of land, uninhabited (most likely) since an evacuation forced by a 1981 eruption; has a grass airstrip
— an enormous, active stratovolcano, sporadically inhabited (in very small numbers) in modern history, but currently vacant
— these three islands are actually the highest points of a single submerged volcano's rim, leaving a deep pool in the middle where the crater would be
— an active volcano sits at the heart of the northernmost of the Marianas, to the south of South Iwo Jima, of the Ogasawara Islands (Japan)
